That railroads contribute greatly to the prosperity of
country, we have too many proofs in the United States tl
doubt. Our sister State of Georgia has, it appears, iJ
creased more in population within the last ten years, in prJ
portion, than any other state in the Union ; and her agricul
ture, manufactures and resources are in a more flourishing
condition than any of the Southern States ; and all this il
attributed mainly to her system of railroads traversing the
whole state.
When I first descended the Mississippi, although then quitl
a youth, I retain a vivid impression of the whole scene: then
was not a white inhabitant on its banks, from the mouth oj
the Ohio to the Walnut Hills, (now Vicksburg.) save at Xel
Madrid and neighborhood. The whole valley of the Mia
sissippi contained but a few thousand souls : its whole trad]
was carried on in a few flat and keel boats. Steamboat!
were ihen not known. Well do I recollect the sensatiol
created by the landing of the first steamboat at the levee il
New Orleans, in 1812. I happened to be here, and wal
among the passengers on its first departure. Now look a]
the change of scene ! You have now thousands of floating
palaces, gliding, as it were, by magic, along this mighty
stream. This great valley contains now upwards of tea
